message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Computational Models of Argument
Paper Abstract: Research into computational models of argument is a rich interdisciplinary field involving the study of natural, artificial and theoretical argumentation and requiring openness to interactions with a variety of disciplines, ranging from philosophy and cognitive science to formal logic and graph theory. The ultimate aim is to support the development of computer-based systems able to engage in argumentation-related activities, either with human users or among themselves. This book presents the proceedings of the sixth biennial International Conference on Computational Models of Argument (COMMA 2016), held in Potsdam, Germany, on 12- 16 September. The aim of the COMMA conferences is to bring together researchers interested in computational models of argument and the representation of argumentation structures in natural language texts, with special attention to contributions concerning emerging trends and the development of new connections with other areas. The book contains the 25 full papers, 17 short papers and 10 demonstration abstracts presented at the conference, together with 3 invited talks. Subjects covered include abstract, bipolar and structured argumentation, quantitative approaches and their connections with formalisms like Bayesian networks and fuzzy logic, multi-agent scenarios, algorithms and solvers, and mining arguments in text, dialogue, and social media. The book provides an overview of current research and developments in the field of computational models of argument, and will be essential reading for all those with an interest in the field.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

4. **Graph Theory** - concept, uses (structure representation)
5. **Philosophy** - discipline/concept, uses (interdisciplinary aspect)
6. **Cognitive Science** - concept, uses (interdisciplinary aspect)
7. **Abstract Argumentation** - concept, uses (subject covered)

Here are the search results for "Natural language processing":

## Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer, and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## History and Evolution

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.(no content)The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, and the concept of large language models (LLMs) emerged in the late 2010s.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Here are the search results for "Argumentation framework":

## Overview

An argumentation framework is a way to deal with contentious information and draw conclusions from it using formalized arguments in artificial intelligence and related fields.

## Key Types and Variations

**Abstract Argumentation Frameworks:** In an abstract argumentation framework, entry-level information is a set of abstract arguments.

**Logic-Based Frameworks:** In logic-based argumentation frameworks, an argument is a pair where the first part is a minimal consistent set of formulae enough to prove the formula for the second part of the argument.

**Assumption-Based Argumentation:** An assumption-based argumentation framework can be represented in a tree-form.

## Application in Artificial Intelligence

Mechanisms for computing semantics of argumentation frameworks were introduced as a way of providing a calculus of opposition for computing what it is reasonable to believe in the context of conflicting arguments.(no content)Computational argumentation systems have found particular application in domains where formal logic and classical decision theory are unable to capture the richness of reasoning, such as law and medicine.

Here are the search results for "Bayesian networks":

## Overview

Bayesian networks are a modeling tool for assigning probabilities to events, and thereby characterizing the uncertainty in a model's predictions.

## Core Functionality

Bayesian networks are complete models for their variables and their relationships, and can be used to answer probabilistic queries about them. A Bayesian network can be considered a mechanism for automatically applying Bayes' theorem to complex problems.(no content)The network can be used to update knowledge of the state of a subset of variables when other variables (the evidence variables) are observed. This process of computing the posterior distribution of variables given evidence is called probabilistic inference.

## Inference Methods

The most common exact inference methods are: variable elimination, which eliminates the non-observed non-query variables one by one by distributing the sum over the product; clique tree propagation, which caches the computation so that many variables can be queried at one time and new evidence can be propagated quickly; and recursive conditioning and AND/OR search.(no content)The most common approximate inference algorithms are importance sampling, stochastic MCMC simulation, mini-bucket elimination, loopy belief propagation, generalized belief propagation and variational methods.

## Related Models

A dynamic Bayesian network (DBN) is a Bayesian network which relates variables to each other over adjacent time steps.

Here are the search results for "Bayesian networks":

## Overview

Bayesian networks are a modeling tool for assigning probabilities to events, and thereby characterizing the uncertainty in a model's predictions.

## Core Functionality

Bayesian networks are complete models for their variables and their relationships, and can be used to answer probabilistic queries about them. A Bayesian network can be considered a mechanism for automatically applying Bayes' theorem to complex problems.(no content)The network can be used to update knowledge of the state of a subset of variables when other variables (the evidence variables) are observed. This process of computing the posterior distribution of variables given evidence is called probabilistic inference.

## Inference Methods

The most common exact inference methods are: variable elimination, which eliminates the non-observed non-query variables one by one by distributing the sum over the product; clique tree propagation, which caches the computation so that many variables can be queried at one time and new evidence can be propagated quickly; and recursive conditioning and AND/OR search.(no content)The most common approximate inference algorithms are importance sampling, stochastic MCMC simulation, mini-bucket elimination, loopy belief propagation, generalized belief propagation and variational methods.

## Related Models

A dynamic Bayesian network (DBN) is a Bayesian network which relates variables to each other over adjacent time steps.

I've performed a web search for "Graph theory" and found comprehensive information about this mathematical field. Here's what I found:

## Overview of Graph Theory

In mathematics and computer science, graph theory is the study of graphs, which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects.(no content)A graph in this context is made up of vertices (also called nodes or points) which are connected by edges (also called arcs, links or lines).

## Historical Background

The paper written by Leonhard Euler on the Seven Bridges of Königsberg and published in 1736 is regarded as the first paper in the history of graph theory.

## Applications

Graph theory has diverse applications across many fields:

- **Chemistry**: In chemistry a graph makes a natural model for a molecule, where vertices represent atoms and edges bonds.
- **Linguistics**: Graph-theoretic methods have proven particularly useful in linguistics, since natural language often lends itself well to discrete structure, with syntax and compositional semantics traditionally following tree-based structures.
- **Neuroscience**: In computational neuroscience graphs can be used to represent functional connections between brain areas that interact to give rise to various cognitive processes.
- **Sociology**: Graph theory is widely used in sociology as a way to measure actors' prestige or explore rumor spreading through social network analysis.
- **Transportation**: Weighted graphs are commonly used to program GPS's and travel-planning search engines that compare flight times and costs.

Zadeh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotfi_A._Zadeh"}]

## Fuzzy Logic

Fuzzy logic is a form of many-valued logic in which the truth value of variables may be any real number between 0 and 1.(no content)It is employed to handle the concept of partial truth, where the truth value may range between completely true and completely false. This contrasts with Boolean logic, where the truth values of variables may only be the integer values 0 or 1.

### History and Development

The term fuzzy logic was introduced with the 1965 proposal of fuzzy set theory by mathematician Lotfi Zadeh.(no content)Basic fuzzy logic had, however, been studied since the 1920s, as infinite-valued logic—notably by Łukasiewicz and Tarski.

### Foundational Concepts

Fuzzy logic is based on the observation that people make decisions based on imprecise and non-numerical information.(no content)Fuzzy logic uses degrees of truth as a mathematical model of vagueness, while probability is a mathematical model of ignorance.

### Applications

Fuzzy logic has been applied to many fields, from control theory to artificial intelligence.(no content)Firms such as Boeing, General Motors, Allen-Bradley, Chrysler, Eaton, and Whirlpool have worked on fuzzy logic for use in low-power refrigerators, improved automotive transmissions, and energy-efficient electric motors.(no content)Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure".

Here are the search results for "Cognitive science":

## Overview

Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary, scientific study of the mind and its processes, examining the nature, the tasks, and the functions of cognition in a broad sense.(no content)Mental faculties of concern to cognitive scientists include perception, memory, attention, reasoning, and language.

## Interdisciplinary Nature

Cognitive science is an interdisciplinary field with contributors from various fields, including psychology, neuroscience,linguistics, philosophy of mind, computer science, anthropology and biology.(no content)The field regards itself as compatible with the physical sciences and uses the scientific method as well as simulation or modeling, often comparing the output of models with aspects of human cognition.

## Historical Development

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

## Multi-Agent System

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system are at least partially independent and autonomous, and no agent is designated as controlling.(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement, using example languages such as Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

### Components and Structure

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, with research typically referring to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

### Applications and Modern Development

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Systems of formal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Systems_of_formal_logic"},{"title":"Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic"},{"title":"Notre Dame Journal of Formal Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notre_Dame_Journal_of_Formal_Logic"},{"title":"Term logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Term_logic"},{"title":"Mathematical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_logic"},{"title":"Formal proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_proof"},{"title":"Dialectical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialectical_logic"},{"title":"Logic and dialectic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_and_dialectic"},{"title":"Theory (mathematical logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_(mathematical_logic)"},{"title":"Glossary of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of formal logic:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Formal logic is the study of deductively valid inferences or logical truths. It examines how conclusions follow from premises based on the structure of arguments alone, independent of their topic and content.(no content)Formal logic is interested in deductively valid arguments, for which the truth of their premises ensures the truth of their conclusion.(no content)Formal logic (also known as symbolic logic) uses a formal approach to study reasoning: it replaces concrete expressions with abstract symbols to examine the logical form of arguments independent of their concrete content.

## Methods and Tools

Formal logic uses formal languages to express, analyze, and clarify arguments. They normally have a very limited vocabulary and exact syntactic rules. These rules specify how their symbols can be combined to construct sentences, so-called well-formed formulas.

## Historical Development

Modern formal logic has its roots in the work of late 19th-century mathematicians such as Gottlob Frege.(no content)Today, the most commonly used system is classical logic. It consists of propositional logic and first-order logic.

## Applications and Relevance

Logic plays a central role in many fields, such as philosophy, mathematics, computer science, and linguistics.(no content)Mathematical logic is the study of formal logic within mathematics. Major subareas include model theory, proof theory, set theory, and recursion theory (also known as computability theory).

I've performed a web search on "Philosophy" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Philosophy is a systematic study of general and fundamental questions concerning topics like existence, knowledge, mind, reason, language, and value.(no content)It is a rational and critical inquiry that reflects on its methods and assumptions. The word itself comes from Ancient Greek and literally means "love of wisdom".

## Major Branches

Major branches of philosophy are epistemology, ethics, logic, and metaphysics. Additionally, other subfields include aesthetics, philosophy of language, philosophy of mind, philosophy of religion, philosophy of science, philosophy of mathematics, philosophy of history, and political philosophy.

## Philosophical Traditions

Influential traditions in the history of philosophy include Western, Arabic–Persian, Indian, and Chinese philosophy. Each tradition has distinct focuses:
- Chinese philosophy focuses principally on practical issues about right social conduct, government, and self-cultivation.
- Indian philosophy combines the spiritual problem of how to reach enlightenment with the exploration of the nature of reality and the ways of arriving at knowledge.

## Characteristics

Web search results for query: "Argumentation"

Links: [{"title":"Argumentation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory"},{"title":"Argumentation framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_framework"},{"title":"Logic of argumentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_of_argumentation"},{"title":"Argumentation scheme - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_scheme"},{"title":"Term (argumentation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Term_(argumentation)"},{"title":"Talk:Argumentation ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Argumentation_ethics"},{"title":"Argumentation and Advocacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_and_Advocacy"},{"title":"Centre for Research in Reasoning, Argumentation, and Rhetoric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_for_Research_in_Reasoning,_Argumentation,_and_Rhetoric"},{"title":"Argument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument"},{"title":"Argument mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argument_mining"}]

Here are the search results for "Argumentation":

## Overview

Argumentation is one of four rhetorical modes (also known as modes of discourse), along with exposition, description, and narration.(no content)Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning.

## Definition and Scope

With historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric, argumentation theory includes the arts and sciences of civil debate, dialogue, conversation, and persuasion.(no content)Argumentation is a daily occurrence, such as in public debate, science, and law.

## Types and Applications

Argumentation includes various forms of dialogue such as deliberation and negotiation which are concerned with collaborative decision-making procedures. It also encompasses eristic dialogue, the branch of social debate in which victory over an opponent is the primary goal, and didactic dialogue used for teaching.

## Structure of Arguments

An argument is one or more premises—sentences, statements, or propositions—directed towards arriving at a logical conclusion. The purpose of an argument is to give reasons for one's thinking and understanding via justification, explanation, or persuasion.

## Related Fields

Argument mining, or argumentation mining, is a research area within the natural-language processing field. The goal of argument mining is the automatic extraction and identification of argumentative structures from natural language text with the aid of computer programs.

Web search results for query: "Text mining"

Links: [{"title":"Text mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text_mining"},{"title":"List of text mining methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_text_mining_methods"},{"title":"National Centre for Text Mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Centre_for_Text_Mining"},{"title":"List of text mining software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_text_mining_software"},{"title":"Category:Text mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Text_mining"},{"title":"Document clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Document_clustering"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about text mining:

## Definition

Text mining, text data mining (TDM) or text analytics is the process of deriving high-quality information from text.(no content)It involves "the discovery by computer of new, previously unknown information, by automatically extracting information from different written resources."(no content)Written resources may include websites, books, emails, reviews, and articles.

## Process and Methods

Text mining usually involves the process of structuring the input text (usually parsing, along with the addition of some derived linguistic features and the removal of others, and subsequent insertion into a database), deriving patterns within the structured data, and finally evaluation and interpretation of the output.(no content)Typical text mining tasks include text categorization, text clustering, concept/entity extraction, production of granular taxonomies, sentiment analysis, document summarization, and entity relation modeling (i.e., learning relations between named entities).

## Overall Goal

The overarching goal is, essentially, to turn text into data for analysis, via the application of natural language processing (NLP), different types of algorithms and analytical methods.

## Applications

A typical application is to scan a set of documents written in a natural language and either model the document set for predictive classification purposes or populate a database or search index with the information extracted.

I've performed a web search for "Algorithm." Here's a summary of the results:

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, an algorithm is a finite sequence of mathematically rigorous instructions, typically used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.(no content)Algorithms are used as specifications for performing calculations and data processing.

## Key Characteristics

Starting from an initial state and initial input, the instructions describe a computation that, when executed, proceeds through a finite number of well-defined successive states, eventually producing "output" and terminating at a final ending state.

## Historical Background

Around 825 AD, Persian scientist Muḥammad ibn Mūsā al-Khwārizmī wrote texts involving computation, and in the early 12th century, Latin translations of these texts involving the Hindu–Arabic numeral system appeared.(no content)The earliest evidence of algorithms is found in ancient Mesopotamian mathematics, with a Sumerian clay tablet dated to c. 2500 BC describing the earliest division algorithm.

## Common Types

The search results include information about several important algorithms:
- A* is a graph traversal and pathfinding algorithm that is used in many fields of computer science due to its completeness, optimality, and optimal efficiency.
- A greedy algorithm is any algorithm that follows the problem-solving heuristic of making the locally optimal choice at each stage.
- The Euclidean algorithm calculates the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two natural numbers, which is the largest natural number that divides both without leaving a remainder.

Links: [{"title":"Algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithm"},{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"In-place algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In-place_algorithm"},{"title":"Introduction to Algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_Algorithms"},{"title":"List of algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_algorithms"},{"title":"Dijkstra's algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dijkstra's_algorithm"},{"title":"Greedy algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greedy_algorithm"},{"title":"Euclidean algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_algorithm"},{"title":"Shor's algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shor's_algorithm"},{"title":"Symmetric-key algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric-key_algorithm"}]

I've performed a web search for "Algorithm." Here's a summary of the results:

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, an algorithm is a finite sequence of mathematically rigorous instructions, typically used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.(no content)Algorithms are used as specifications for performing calculations and data processing.

## Key Characteristics

Starting from an initial state and initial input, the instructions describe a computation that, when executed, proceeds through a finite number of well-defined successive states, eventually producing "output" and terminating at a final ending state.

## Historical Background

Around 825 AD, Persian scientist Muḥammad ibn Mūsā al-Khwārizmī wrote texts involving computation, and in the early 12th century, Latin translations of these texts involving the Hindu–Arabic numeral system appeared.(no content)The earliest evidence of algorithms is found in ancient Mesopotamian mathematics, with a Sumerian clay tablet dated to c. 2500 BC describing the earliest division algorithm.

## Common Types

The search results include information about several important algorithms:
- A* is a graph traversal and pathfinding algorithm that is used in many fields of computer science due to its completeness, optimality, and optimal efficiency.
- A greedy algorithm is any algorithm that follows the problem-solving heuristic of making the locally optimal choice at each stage.
- The Euclidean algorithm calculates the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two natural numbers, which is the largest natural number that divides both without leaving a remainder.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** This paper is a **survey** - it's a conference proceedings collection that presents and reviews existing research.

**Triples Extracted:** I've identified and validated 12 key triples from the paper's title and abstract:

1. **Argumentation theory** - The core subject and foundation
2. **Natural language processing** - For mining arguments from text
3. **Logic** - Theoretical foundation for computational models
4. **Graph theory** - For representing argumentation structures
5. **Philosophy** - Interdisciplinary theoretical foundation
6. **Cognitive science** - Understanding human reasoning
7. **Argumentation framework** - Core computational model
8. **Bayesian network** - Formalism for quantitative approaches
9. **Fuzzy logic** - Handling uncertainty in models
10. **Multi-agent system** - For multi-agent scenarios
11. **Algorithm** - Computational algorithms and solvers
12. **Text mining** - Mining arguments from various sources

All triples have been validated against Wikipedia and properly formatted with:
- Correct Wikipedia URLs
- Appropriate entity types (concept, method, tool)
- Relations set to "uses" (since this is a survey compiling existing work)
- Clear relevance statements

**Validation Result:** ✅ PASSED - All 12 triples validated successfully!
